LARONIDASE

  • Indications and doses
  • Drug action
  • Pregnancy
  • Side effects
  • Administration
  • Cautions
  • Monitoring requirements
  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Non-neurological manifestations of mucopolysaccharidosis I (specialist use only),

By intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    100 units/kg once weekly.

Drug action

Laronidase is an enzyme produced by recombinant DNA technology licensed for long-term replacement therapy in the treatment of non-neurological manifestations of mucopolysaccharidosis I, a lysosomal storage disorder caused by deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises avoid unless essential—no information available.

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Abdominal pain, alopecia, anaphylaxis, angioedema, blood pressure changes, cold extremities, cough, diarrhoea, dizziness, dyspnoea, fatigue, flushing, headache, influenza-like symptoms, infusion-site reactions, musculoskeletal pain, nausea, pain in extremities, pallor, paraesthesia, pruritus, rash, restlessness, tachycardia, urticaria, vomiting,

notKnown: Bronchospasm, infusion-related reactions, respiratory arrest,

Infusion-related reactions

Infusion-related reactions often occur, they can be managed by slowing the infusion rate or interrupting the infusion, and can be minimised by pre-treatment with an antihistamine and an antipyretic. Recurrent infusion-related reactions may require pre-treatment with a corticosteroid—consult product literature for details.

Directions for administration

With intravenous use

For intravenous infusion (Aldurazyme ) intermittent in Sodium chloride 0.9%; body-weight under 20 kg, use 100 mL infusion fluid; body-weight over 20 kg use 250 mL infusion fluid; withdraw volume of infusion fluid equivalent to volume of laronidase concentrate being added; give through in-line filter (0.22 micron) initially at a rate of 2 units/kg/hour then increase gradually every 15 minutes to max. 43 units/kg/hour.

Cautions regarding administration

  • Infusion-related reactions can occur

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibody concentration.

Prepared medicinal forms of LARONIDASE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for infusion
